metadata.case_name: Bhagwantrao Shivaji Patel v. Vishwasrao Patel & State of Bombay

facts.text: Lands in suit comprised in six survey numbers in village Nawabag, a jagir village of Ellichpur (Archalpur) taluq of Berar.

Four families of Patels (Dongre, Rokade, Raut, Ingle) held Patel office in rotation of ten years each. Concerned with Rokade family: Shivajirao had sons Amrit and Bhagwantrao (appellant). Vishwasrao (respondent No.1) son of Amrit.
Shivajirao died in 1886. Amrit died in 1920.
Partition in 1923 between appellant (Bhagwantrao) and respondent No.1 (Vishwasrao). Appellant claimed patelki inam lands allotted to his share.
Shivajirao, Amrit, and Vishwasrao worked as Patel in turn.

In 1935, special officer appointed to prepare record of rights for Nawabag jagir. Report led to enquiries; Deputy Commissioner ordered resumption of lands in appellant's possession and regrant to working Patel (Vishwasrao).
Appellant appealed; Commissioner of Berar set aside eviction order, maintained status quo pending Government orders.
On December 19, 1941, Financial Commissioner held working Patel entitled to full emoluments, set aside Commissioner's order, restored Deputy Commissioner's.
Appellant filed suit in 1942 claiming Government had no jurisdiction to resume/regrant lands, orders null and void; sought possession and mesne profits.
Amendment to plaint: Plots 2/1A and 9/1A ceased to be patelki inam lands, became private property.
Trial Judge dismissed suit. Additional District Judge (Amraoti) decreed suit on appeal. High Court of Nagpur allowed second appeal, restored trial decree.

High Court held: (1) Lands granted as remuneration/emoluments for Patel services, recognized as service inam; (2) Revenue authorities could resume/regrant under Patels and Patwaris Law, 1900 and s.190 Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928.
Certificate granted by High Court under Art. 133(1)(c) for appeal to Supreme Court.
Jagir of Nawabag granted by Kings of Delhi to Shah Abdul Huq, confirmed by Nizam in 1757. Total area 1846 bighas, 262 bighas as patelki inam at 1 bigha per netan.
Ex.P-9A (1771): Dispute between jagirdars and patels over 1.5 bighas per netan; Nazim confirmed grant from year to year per old usage.
Berar ceded by Nizam in 1853; Inam Rules 1859. Inam entry Ex.P-1 (1866): Jagir continued except 200 bighas, patelki inam excluded.
Rokade family held about 11 plots, 50 acres of patelki inam.

Before 1904, jagirdars alienated lands; Government resumed half jagir in 1904-05. Survey nos. 1-21,40-45 patelki lands in resumed portion (Khalsa, assessed); 22-39 in jagir portion (unassessed). Plots 2/1A,9/1A in resumed, recorded Khalsa.
1917 resumption: Alienations in jagir portion; lands regranted to jagirdars, not made Khalsa.
Jagirdars claimed patelki lands; led to proceedings. Government letter 28.8.1922: Excluded 25a15g khalsa, 24a30g inam portion; recorded in Amrit Shivaji Patel's name as patelki huq inam.
Other Patel families' claims rejected except Amritrao.
1935-1941 proceedings: Third resumption of patelki lands, regrant to Vishwasrao.

legal_issues.text: True nature of patelki inam lands: grant by way of remuneration/emoluments for Patel's office, or grant of land to patelki family burdened with service (joint family lands subject to partition)?
Whether Government had jurisdiction/authority to resume and regrant lands to working Patel under relevant laws.
Status of plots 2/1A and 9/1A: ceased to be patelki inam, private property?
Claim of title by adverse possession to patelki lands.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rights of Rokade family were as owners subject to rendering service; grant was land burdened with service.
Grant made by jagirdar, not sovereign; Inam Rules/Patels and Patwaris Law 1900 inapplicable.
Even if laws applied, appellant retained hereditary rights in lands.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Inam Rules V, VI; Patels and Patwaris Law 1900

petitioner_arguments.text: 1922 orders conferred no new right, deprived no subsisting right; Government no right to resume/regrant.
Plots 2/1A, 9/1A ceased to be inam (fell in resumed Khalsa portion 1904-05), sold by jagirdars; appellant obtained decrees/possession.

respondent_arguments.text: Lands granted as emoluments for services; service inam resumable/regrantable to working Patel.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Patels and Patwaris Law 1900; Berar Land Revenue Code s.190

respondent_arguments.text: Patelki inam independent of jagir; ancient grant by sovereign confirmed.

court_reasoning.text: Kararnama 1771 and Inam entry 1866 show grant by sovereign as annual remuneration for services, binding on jagirdars.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dispute over remuneration implies emoluments, not family land grant.

court_reasoning.text: Overwhelming evidence patelki inam separate/independent of jagir: 1906-08 appointments by revenue authorities, not jagirdars; 1908 SDO order; Commissioner Sly; 1918 Financial Commissioner; 1922 exclusion order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Patels village servants responsible to Government, watan independent.

court_reasoning.text: Documents/statements (Amrit 1908, 1917; appellant as agent) confirm lands in lieu of emoluments/wages.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parties understood as remuneration; alienations resumed by Government.

court_reasoning.text: Inam Rules 1859: Not hereditary share for non-serving family; emoluments to office-holder (Rule II, VI(8), XIV(2), XXI(2)).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No right to share irrespective of service.

court_reasoning.text: Patels and Patwaris Law 1900 s.3,9,10,11,20: Emoluments solely to holder; no attachment/sale/assignment; civil court jurisdiction barred.
Berar Land Revenue Code s.190: Power to forfeit/resume service lands if conditions defeated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.192 bars civil suits on revenue matters.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents distinguish but none support family share in Patel emoluments.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No decision holds member entitled to share; Government can resume.

court_reasoning.text: Plots 2/1A,9/1A: Decrees not for these plots; treated as homogeneous with other patelki lands in 1922 order.
No adverse possession against Government for emolument lands; open to resume post-1923.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Requires establishing share right, which fails.

holdings.text: Patelki inam lands are grant by way of emoluments/remuneration for Patel's office, not family land burdened with service.
Revenue authorities had jurisdiction to resume/regrant to working Patel under Inam Rules, Patels and Patwaris Law 1900, Berar Land Revenue Code s.190.
No hereditary share right for non-serving family member.
Plots 2/1A,9/1A remain patelki inam; no private title/adverse possession.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied on; distinction between office remunerated by land vs land burdened with service.
Jagir case, ordinary inam village partitionable unless impartible/service; not Patel emoluments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mir Subhan Ali v. Imami Begum
precedents_cited.relevance: Inam Rules regulate devolution if not in sanad; not service grant or Patel share.
Distinction: office+land remuneration resumable; land+service not prima facie.
Inam certificate allowed sharer possession; specific terms.
Non-service grant; Hindu Law primogeniture not applicable.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Inam Rules, 1859 (Berar)
statutes_cited.relevance: Settlement of inams; service grants not divisible/hereditary shares for non-servants; resumable.

statutes_cited.name: Patels and Patwaris Law, 1900 (Berar)
statutes_cited.relevance: Emoluments solely to office-holder; rotation; no attachment/sale/assignment; civil jurisdiction barred.

statutes_cited.name: Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928
statutes_cited.relevance: Forfeiture/resumption of service lands if conditions defeated; civil suits barred on revenue matters.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed. Supreme Court upheld High Court: patelki inam lands are emoluments for Patel's office, resumable by revenue authorities and regrantable to working Patel. No family share right; special claims to plots 2/1A,9/1A and adverse possession rejected.

key_quotes.text: "the grant was from year to year in lieu of patelki services and was binding on the jagirdars who agreed to be bound by it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes nature as annual emoluments, not permanent family grant.

key_quotes.text: "the Patel family has had watandari rights for certainly 150 years or so. I am of opinion therefore that the watan seems independent of the jagir."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court

key_quotes.text: "Section 9 ... the emoluments appertaining to the office of the patel ... shall be enjoyed solely by the person for the time being holding the office"
key_quotes.speaker: court
